thinking.disposable_income: Norwood Park is an upper-middle-class area with median household income around $82,000. Residents have relatively high disposable income compared to Chicago average, making them less sensitive to moderate fare/fee increases
thinking.discretionary_consumption: High levels of discretionary spending capacity. Many households own cars and can afford higher transportation costs. The 1-1.5% sales tax impact would be noticeable but manageable given income levels
thinking.accessibility: Located on far northwest side with good access to Blue Line and Metra. High car ownership rates (~90% households have cars). Most residents drive but want transit options. Average commute involves mix of driving and transit
thinking.decision_rationale:
1. Prioritize policies that improve both driving and transit times while keeping costs moderate - residents use both modes
2. Can accept moderate tax/fee increases given income levels if they yield better service
3. Focus on balanced proposals that don't extremely favor one mode
4. Prefer proposals with 1% tax over 1.5% given community's high consumption
5. Value driving time improvements but want viable transit option
6. Selected proposals 14, 13, 11, 10, 4 as they offer good time savings for both modes with moderate cost increases
